PIG FARMING IN PUNGGOL
(Continuance of)


    2. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development and Communications whether he can give an assurance that pig farmers who have been resettled will be able to continue their pig farming activity for a period beyond 15 years as many of them have been resettled on more than one occasion and heavy capital is involved in the setting up of pig farms.

    Dr Tan Eng Liang (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the pig farmers have been resettled in Punggol because it is a non-water catchment area where pig waste does not create the same

Column: 193

serious pollution problems as in a water catchment area.

    The Government has so far developed 507 hectares (1,252 acres) of land in Punggol at considerable expense for pig farming as part of our policy to be self-sufficient in protein food. Also 30-year leases are given to large commercial pig farms. Therefore, as far as I can see, pig farming is likely to continue there for the next 15 years.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, in that case, I must thank the Senior Minister of State for his kind comments. Sir, would he not agree with me that the farmers will be there for more than 15 years?

    Dr Tan Eng Liang: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have categorically stated that pig farming is likely to continue there for the next 15 years. The very fact that we have given leases of 30 years, we can even speculate that it is very likely that pig farming will be there for 15 to 30 years.

Column: 193

PUNGGOL VETERINARY EXTENSION CENTRE


    3. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development and Communications if it is planned to expand the Punggol veterinary extension centre to meet the increasing demand for veterinary services with the rapid expansion of the pig farming industry in Punggol.

    Dr Tan Eng Liang (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is yes. In fact, a new 2-storey addition to the existing veterinary centre costing $409,000 with a built-up area of 702 sq. m. is under construction and will be completed by the end of this year. This new building will have a laboratory complex, a post-mortem room, offices, a library and a meeting room.

    Three veterinary surgeons and other supporting staff will be posted to the Centre to provide more efficient diagnostic, treatment and advisory services to the farms.

PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS

Debate on the Address
(Third Day)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [14th February, 1977],

    `That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:-

    "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore. express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the opening of the First Session of this Parliament.".'. - [Dr Chiang Hai Ding].

    Question again proposed.

2.37 p.m.

    The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Fong Sip Chee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I had originally intended to take advantage of the Standing Orders to table an amendment to the Motion standing in the name of the hon. Member for Ulu Pandan in expressing our thanks to the President for his speech. Several Members have, in fact, indicated that they expected another diabolical manifestation of what other Members might describe as the negative part of my nature.

    Notwithstanding the lifting of the Whip, and the assurance given by the Leader of the House, I am still inhibited by the fear that being a Member on the Government Bench, an amendment might well be regarded as a gesture of disrespect to the President. Further, having listened to the gentlemanly and eloquent delivery of the speech by the hon. Member for Ulu Pandan, I have come to the conclusion that any amendment to the Motion will certainly be repugnant. I decided, therefore, that the Motion should remain as it is, at least for the sake of etiquette, and I shall try, though not without involuntary

Column: 195

restraint, to be less pungent in my remarks at this Sitting.

    Without formally moving the amendment, I think that the Motion should more appropriately read as follows:

    `We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore. express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the opening of the First Session of this Parliament, but regret to note the absence of any mention on the deficiency of the Government in the understanding of the problems of the people in the process of implementing its policies'

    Seriously speaking, Mr Speaker, Sir, few can dispute the high ideals expressed in the Addenda, some of which are so colourfully dressed with so many jargons, except to marvel a little in disbelief in some of the many intangibles and inadequacies so innocently confessed through the statements in both the Addenda to the Ministry of Education and the Ministry of Culture.

    Sir, I recall that some years ago, the Deputy Prime Minister, in a speech that typified his in-depth knowledge in the potentials and prejudices of our people, went to great lengths to define the characteristics of what he called "Westernised Oriental Gentlemen", or WOGs as the Deputy Prime Minister endeared these people with that abbreviation. That speech was both enriching and invigorating. Indeed, it provoked serious mind-searching.

    I would have been quite satisfied with my comprehension of that speech if I had stopped just there. However, in giving his observations a little further probing, I discovered that the Government is not totally free from the symptoms of such decried qualities.

    Allow me to recapture just two previous instances which, I hope, will suffice to demonstrate the lack of understanding on the part of the Government in both the culture and traditions, which values the Ministries of Education and Culture so doggedly promised in the Addenda to inculcate in our young.

Column: 196



    Some years ago, as a result of complaints of noise pollution, the Government imposed a partial ban on cracker-firing. The letting off of fire crackers was made an offence except in places designated as permitted areas, such as State-owned - I emphasise State-owned - open land and community centre compounds. Many Members are aware in my discussions with them, in the Members' Room, that I was quite vocal against this kind of a half-line action. I then held the view, and I still hold the view now, that the partial ban was doomed to failure. If the firing of crackers was regarded as obnoxious - indeed it proved to be unconducive to our well-being, apart from being an annual money-wasting folly, then the ban should have been total.

    This "half-way-house" policy succeeded only to expose the Government's ignorance in our culture and its complete lack of understanding of the meaning and significance of cracker firing. It was, and still is, believed - total ban now notwithstanding, that the ear-shattering explosions promise a whole host of things, from scaring away evil spirits to bringing good luck and fortune to the family and the household, not to forget that noise-making has been part and parcel of the local mode of celebrations. In fact, Sir, in funerals we happen to make the most noise.

    No one, therefore, would spend money to bring good luck to Government-owned designated places. Fortunately, these superstitious exercises remained as superstition, for otherwise, those who took advantage of that `leeway' would have succeeded in bringing good fortune to the designated places, perhaps even raised the land value which, of course, must consequently be put up for tender under the Urban Renewal Schemes.

    So this `leeway' proved to be neither here nor there. Eventually, as a result of a nasty accident, a total ban was slammed. The nett result of that short-lived concession was a 100% disagreement from the populace. For those who favoured total banning, the frightening sound of crackers could still be

Column: 197

heard; and for those who refused to warm up the designated places, they were utterly frustrated. So much for one example of Government understanding of our culture and tradition.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I speak without inhibition now, and as the Minister for Health is not here, it is not my intention to dispute the success of family planning in Singapore. On the contrary, I am confident that we will achieve our target even more effectively, now that the programme has been reinforced, I hope, with new vigor and approach by the present Minister for Health.

    There was a time, Members will remember, when there was great hullabaloo in this House on the subject. Hon. Members will recall the day when the House was entertained to some very amusing definitions as to what an ideal family should be. Briefly, we were told that a one-child family would be too lonely for the poor child; two would of course be most ideal; three would be a luxury; four would be unpardonably anti social, and five, God forbid, criminal.

    The population problem, in Singapore's context, is a problem not unrelated to Asian values. If a Western solution is the only feasible solution to this Asian problem, so be it. It has got to be done, and so it must be done. I do not think that our people would quarrel with the concept, or even with the incentives or disincentives. But the explanation, propaganda, publicity and exhortations must necessarily be Asian. There are equally convincing axioms in Asian teachings and philosophies to get our people around to adopt family planning without resorting to threats and name-calling. Here again is what I suspect to be another WOG thinking.

    Recent examples of WOGs at work in Government policies are abundant, but it may be a relief for our Ministers in the Front Bench to note that they are not alone in the pursuit of this title. In fact, only yesterday, they were mirrored in the appeal by one such latest exponent. This time, however, the title award must go to none other than the hon.

Column: 198

Member for Telok Blangah, who so seriously advocated, of course, with detectable traces here and there of imperfect imitation of the Dale Carnegie style, for the implementation of Daylight Saving Time.

    Sir, I am no geographer, neither am I a pilot. But I do know that Singapore is approximately situated at Lat. 1 degree 21 minutes from the equator, and if it pleases the hon. Member for Telok Blangah. I might add that we are north of the equator, where the sun rises every morning at about 6 am, and sets every evening around 6.45 to 7.00 p.m. Daylight saving certainly is useful to countries further to the north of the equator, such as the United Kingdom. (The hon. Member for Telok Blangah might even tell us that he knows exactly the latitude of London.) I was a poor geography student and I did not quite get myself round to the coordinates of longitudes and latitudes. Sir, the episode does not end here. A colleague in this House, who happens to be on the other side of the House, suggested to me out of kindness that an alternative might well be to advance the working hours by one hour. Sir, in fact, last evening, we were trying to extend the time up to 6 o'clock and I was thinking that we ought to be home for dinner at not to forget, that would be after two hours of recreation. Sir, that was a suggestion with the hope that it would not upset everybody or confusing the geographers or the pilots.

    I received the suggestion with some reservation, as I am conscious of my official position in the Ministry of Labour, under which portfolio the question of working hours sometimes constitutes a rather unpleasant subject in negotiations. I will therefore leave it to this kind Gentleman on the other side of the House to muster sufficient courage to appease the hon. Member for Telok Blangah with that proposal. But to be fair to that Member, Sir, I did caution him that in the event he decides to risk his reputation in offering this counter proposal seriously, his arguments had better be of such high standard so that he may not, at the end of the exchange of the conversation, emerge as

Column: 199

being one who is bemoaned of lacking in eloquence and found wanting in wisdom.

    Sir, I must apologise to the House for wasting your time by dwelling too lengthily and ironically on the question of saving time by wasting your time. Allow me now to acquaint you with a game which I shall call `cancelling-out' for the time being until we find a better name. The players in this game involve two parties, namely, the Ministry of Education and of course, its worthy opponent - the Ministry of Culture. [Laughter] Let us not laugh and dismiss this game too lightly, because in the end, we, the spectators, will turn out to be the real losers.

    Briefly, the game is very simple. The principle is: Whatever you can do, I can cancel. Accordingly, whatever the Ministry of Education does, the Ministry of Culture promptly cancels out with an equally, and sometimes more effective counter-action. This process is then repeated with the procedure reversed.

    Let me first weigh the stake which we stand to lose so that we can watch the game with more vested interests. If this rather stupid game does not stop, I fear that the more successful the Ministries of Education and Culture in their efforts to -

    The Minister for Health (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, Sir, on a point of clarification. I just wish to question the Member for Kampong Chai Chee. He was the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Culture. We would like to know which side he is speaking for and whether he was cancelling out the Ministry of Education,

    Mr Fong Sip Chee: Sir, I left the Ministry of Culture about five years ago. When I left the Ministry, it was in a happier state, Sir, I am quite confident in saying that at that time the cancelling-out exercise was never mooted and it was a very much happier Ministry. After I left, I cannot vouch whether this Ministry is indeed the same as before. Apparently it is not, Sin, because now the cancelling-out exercise is so blatant and I

Column: 200

shall relate more later, I had expected the hon. Minister for Health to take me on family planning. I was caught.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, Sir, now that I am here I will be very happy to listen to the Member for Kampong Chai Chee on his remarks on family planning. I can enlighten him. I can also send him to my Family Planning Population Board for advice, if necessary.

    Mr Fong Sip Chee: I am sorry. Sir, the hon. Minister missed the boat, as I' have mentioned it earlier. Lest he gets anxious, those remarks were complimentary. I think I should know better, Sir, if you know what I mean.

    Allow me to go on, Sir. As I was saying, if this rather stupid game does not stop, I fear that the more successful the Ministries of Education and Culture in their efforts to "imbibe the tried and tested Asian cultural and moral values", the more they are successful, the more resentment we will have to face. There will be more antiestablishment sentiments, not so much due to the lack of understanding of our national problems on the part of the people, but due to our own default in not understanding them.

    Really, Sir, the questions that we should ask ourselves are: Just what are these values and traditions that are so vital to our survival as a nation? And how are we going to achieve these great objectives set out for us?

    No attempt has been made in the Addenda to list out what those values, culture and traditions are. Even if the Ministries did try, there must be so many contradictions rendering the exercise a wholly frustrating one. This might well be a case of the 10, in this game two blind men trying to decide what an elephant looked like.

    So, Mr Speaker, Sir, their handicap left us with nothing but disorientated compasses with which we are to take part in this cultural treasure-hunt. The most profitable approach in this confusion, I presume, is by taking stock of what has been going on and take a

Column: 201

count on the scoreboards of these two players.

    Perhaps we should begin with a conclusion already at hand. This approach certainly appears odd, rather unprofessional, even unenlightened and unorthodox to begin studying a problem. The conclusion is: discourage all traditional operas, or wayangs as they are known, at least make it difficult for their stagings, because this will be the best way to `encourage' one aspect of cultural heritage which our people are endowed with - by killing it.

    The Ministry of Culture, of course, pledged:

    `to organise a wide range of activities to promote a better appreciation of our cultural heritage. This will provide our young with the necessary cultural ballast against the erosion of traditional norms and values.'

    Just what are these norms and how wide is this wide range of activities? Music, or Art for Everyone, lyrics competitions? How are these activities able to provide the cultural ballast?

    An answer, if possible, would be welcome. If not, then may I venture to provide one: All these utterances have been repeated year after year in this House. The result: rampant drug abuse, still no cultural ballast in sight.

    To define the meaning of "traditional", the Ministry preceded by stating that:

    `It is Government policy to develop Singapore's rich cultural heritage derived from the Malay, Chinese, Indian and western civilisations'

    So, Western civilisation enjoys the confidence of the Ministry of Culture and becomes acceptable as part of our tradition. Interestingly, the Ministry of Education has different ideas. It stated in its Addendum:

    '...they will be taught not to adopt the life styles and values of the West that are alien and pernicious to Singapore society.'

    I hope that this is genuinely the case of the right hand not knowing what the left hand is doing, because if indeed one hand knows exactly what the other hand does, then this mutually cancelling-out exercise must give rise to doubts as to the seriousness and

Column: 202

sincerity of the Government in our cultural policy.

    Let us now take a look at a few more scores in this game that has been going on for too long a time. The schools encourage our young to be thrifty and this is challenged by the television which advises them to buy, or pester their parents to buy what they or their parents do not need. The school says you must save money and open a POSB account, and the same TV teases you and the parents by suggesting why wait for such a long time to get so little money, buy Toto and your problems will be solved.

    The school reminds our children that there is no substitute for hard work, do not try to get rich quick. But the TV says, "Decidedly wrong! The Big Sweep is the alternative". In fact, the advertisements for Toto and the Big Sweep sounded so convincing that few people regard it foolish not to throw away a good portion of their salary so as not to be left out as non-starters.

    The Ministry of Education regards Western life styles and values as alien and pernicious to Singapore. The TV, however, offers effective anti-thesis to this proposition, one of which is through the sometimes less than tasteful advertisement for new jeans. They say new generation jeans but they do not tell you the period between two generations. Is it six months or one year? So you buy new jeans.

    Again, the Ministry of Education takes great pains in including in its curricula subjects such as music appreciation, even resuscitate Civics under the cover of Education for Living, and finally the annual gigantic Youth Festival. But the TV holds steadfast to their ground. TV programmes have been equally successful in forcing down our throat poorly produced so called local cultural shows, stuffed with crazy, frequently `electrifying' dances. Electrifying indeed they are - if only we can find out why those healthy and able-bodied young men and women struggle in agony resembling electric shocks or anything but what the Education Ministry thinks of cultural dances.

Column: 203



    Sir, we now come to the interesting part. Refusing to be sidelined in this cancelling-out ingenuity, the Ministry of Education also shoots into its own goal. To encourage thrift, for example again, they change text books even more frequently than they change their Ministers.

    In its zeal to recover its tarnished image, the Ministry of Education boldly stated in its Addendum:

    `The education system has been revised to improve its effectiveness. Consequently the enormous wastage II underline) in terms of pupils not benefiting from the system and having to leave school prematurely will be drastically reduced'

Is this an ideal, or is it not, as it sounded in the addendum, a statement amounting to an indictment of all the previous efforts of the so many Ministers for Education? Enormous wastage will be drastically reduced. That means in the past there must have been enormous wastage.

    The success of our education can best be reflected in what one hon. Member described to me as the `Goondu' TV shows, at which generous prizes were given away to hide embarrassment. In this series, simple questions were asked of the participants and invariably, astounding, if not outraging answers were promptly proffered. Blessed is the poor goondu who finds the right answer to the question on how many Ministers for Education there were in the last 17 years!

    The mischiefs of WOGs unfortunately, are only one of the shots in a double barrel gun. The Housing and Development Board rightfully claims the right to trigger off the second shot. This time it is not WOG, but Santa Claus is at fault. Building decent houses for the people is the responsibility of the Board and it was for this need that the Board was established in 1960. Whilst it is true that the Board has done much in what its Chief Executive is paid for, success has carried them away to the extent that they, and only they, are the saviours of Singapore. The Board is the philanthropist for whom

Column: 204

hon. Members in this House must labour in return for its kindness!

    Hon. Members are not capable to advise the Board, still less influence its policy. We have been assigned a task only to explain its actions and, worse still, to justify its misdoing. Sir, we stand on the platform. They do not. So we have to justify their misdoings. This, I am sure, Mr Speaker, Sir, is not a complaint only personal to myself. The hon. Member for Changi spoke on his part of the woes in this House yesterday, and I am sure other Members will also certainly have their share of woes too.

    No mention is made in the Ministry of National Development Addendum under the subject on "Housing and Public Projects" as to how the HDB proposes to alleviate the plight of the one-roomers. Other housing estates may not be that bad, but if you go to Manila Street you will find that you have communal kitchens. Then you will know what it is. Many years ago, I cautioned in this House that the one-room units would degenerate into slums over a short period of time. No heed was paid to Parliamentary discussion. To the HDB, we appear to them as nothing more than a debating society.

    Let me remind whoever lives under that illusion that we in this House survive because of his or their works, will certainly be very grossly mistaken. Again, Sir,I cautioned about the high plot ratio commercial development at the city centre, which inevitably must generate a high volume of traffic, particularly the Shenton Way and the Golden Shoe area. Today, we have the CBD restriction and the Area Licensing as our jackpot.

    It would have been a different matter if public applicants from the traditional slum areas were to apply for HDB accommodation, but the one-roomers are, hon. Members will agree, if I were to describe this short-sighted design of first generation flats as Government Planned Modernised Slum. Has not the HDB an obligation to do something for these poor folks?

Column: 205



    Despite repeated appeals by Members of Parliament, the HDB has been completely oblivious to the problem. From recent statements, we have been assured that action will be taken to resettle these one-roomers into larger units, but the whole process would take three to four years. Is this not an admission that the HDB has not been responding to appeals by MPs until recently?

    Various proposals were offered. One involved the conversion of these one-room units into larger two-room units by combining them; another was to demolish a number of blocks to make way for green areas and playing fields - this is a deficiency in planning now requiring rectification.

    It may be worthwhile for HDB to take note of Members' views, if they accept that Parliament, not their drawing office, is the supreme body in this Republic. I must state that in this matter, we shall not succumb to their whims and fancies.

    There is no need for us to look far for inspirations to this conversion programme. These one-room units can easily be retained and converted for a variety of uses, to name only a few:

    (1) Homes for the Aged - The design of these units is ideal for conversion into dormitories for the aged so that they can live as part of the community in a HDB estate, without having to suffer the feeling of being treated as castaways in some remote homes. In all probability, some of these units might actually be so converted, because I have great confidence, very rare confidence though, in the HDB's ability in quickly responding to the recent calls for the care of the aged made by so many Ministers. One up for the HDB on this.

    (2) A less rewarding proposition for the HDB. For areas urgently in need of community centres and lacking in suitable sites a conversion may be the most expeditious solution, although the superstructure may present some technical problems but these are not insurmountable.

    (3) Conversion of some of these units to provide for alternative accommodations for

Column: 206

civic organisations affected by development schemes or urban renewal protects. One must not forget that our civic organisations, whilst handicapped by old fashioned management methods, have proved themselves to be useful and effective in serving the community in the past. I have no doubt that given help, they will continue to be so in the future. Through their mutual assistance, such as scholarship for their members' children, they have been able to partially, maybe negligibly, relieve the State of the heavy burden on education and social services. It is only too unfortunate that nobody thought it useful or necessary to make fuller studies into the more positive aspects of their works.

    The Resettlement Department is the most controversial unit in this glamorous HDB outfit. This Department is even more hard-pressed to perform the dual functions of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde. A not very helpful Dr Jekyll but certainly a monstrous Mr Hyde. I will tell you why.

    The Dr Jekyll role is portrayed through the hypocritical claim of help given to those affected by redevelopment. The common claim is that those affected and entitled to resettlement benefits, are reminded that they enjoy concessionary rents, etc. Let me say that these concessions are no concessions at all. They are entitlements. These people are entitled to these so-called goodies because they have been uprooted from their steady livelihood, having to plunge into uncertainties in the new environment and to re-establish themselves once again. It is only over and above all these `concessions' that the HDB can then justifiably claim to offer concessions.

    Mr Hyde's role is understandably less humane. Permanent residents are not entitled to rehousing nor business premises. I agree that permanent residents should not be entertained when applying for HDB accommodation under the normal public application, but in the case of resettlement, it is highly immoral that they be deprived of alternative housing or place of business. After all, the HDB requires them to quit,

Column: 207

otherwise they are quite contented with the status quo, and pose no burden on the HDB, knowing that they do not qualify for HDB accommodation which I understand about 95 to 100 thousand of citizen families are on the waiting list.

    This leads me on to the unfavourable world economic conditions referred to by the Ministry of Finance, Early last year, in this Chamber, I warned that economic recovery in the industrial countries might stall because of insufficient new investments. This has been clearly vindicated by events. The main reason is that the rate of technological innovations appears to have slowed down in the advanced countries, therefore leading to fewer investments. At the same time, the aging population structure in those countries has altered the pattern of demand, necessitating painful and difficult changes in production patterns because in the aftermath of the Second World War there was a big population boom all over the world, even in the advanced countries. This big population boom gave rise to a lot of demand, initially for maternity services, nurseries, kindergartens, schools, colleges, universities, teen-age fashions like 2nd generation jeans and so on and so forth. But since the early sixties, the rate of population growth in the advanced countries had declined very drastically so that the numbers of young people in some cases, have gone down not only as a proportion of population but also in absolute numbers. So those industries catering to the demands of the young suffer excess capacity.

    At the same time, Sir, there are many more older people proportionately as well as absolutely in the advanced countries, and we are catching up in this respect. In America, I understand about 10% of the population are above the age of 60. This means that they would demand wheel chairs, nursing care and so on and so forth. Therefore, both on the supply side and the demand side, there has been these
